thread.title: Nasdaq jumps 2.3%, closes above 5,000 on tech earnings
thread.title_full: Nasdaq jumps 2.3%, closes above 5,000 on tech earnings

title: Nasdaq jumps 2.3%, closes above 5,000 on tech earnings
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Sun, Oct 25, 2015, 01:32 GMT - UK Markets closed Nasdaq jumps 2.3%, closes above 5,000 on tech earnings AFP â€“ Fri, Oct 23, 2015 21:57 BST View Photo 

US stocks rose sharply Friday following strong earnings from Microsoft (NasdaqGS: MSFT - news ) , Google parent Alphabet (Xetra: ABEA.DE - news ) and Amazon that pushed the Nasdaq (NasdaqGS: NDAQ - news ) above 5,000 for the first time in two months. 
The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index soared 111.82 points (2.27 percent) to 5,031.86, its first close above 5,000 since August 19. 
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 157.54 (0.90 percent) to 17,646.70, while the S&P 500 gained 22.64 (1.10 percent) at 2,075.15. 
Microsoft jumped 10.1 percent, Alphabet 7.7 percent and Amazon 6.2 percent after all three tech giants wowed markets with higher profits, as well as big revenue gains for Alphabet and Amazon. 
The good feeling about earnings from these three companies lifted other big tech stocks, including Apple (Swiss: AAPL.SW - news ) (+3.1 percent), Facebook (+2.5 percent) and Netflix (Hanover: NFC.HA - news ) (+2.8 percent). 
Even Yahoo, which reported disappointing earnings earlier in the week, rose 4.7 percent, while IBM (NYSE: IBM - news ) , another earnings laggard, advanced 0.4 percent. 
US-listed Chinese companies Alibaba surged 6.5 percent and Internet search company Baidu (Xetra: A0F5DE - news ) rose 2.7 percent, benefitting from both the positive sentiment towards tech stocks and a move by the People's Bank of China (HKSE: 3988-OL.HK - news ) to cut benchmark interest rates. 
Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) of large banks pushed higher, including JPMorgan Chase (Swiss: JPM.SW - news ) (+1.1 percent), Citigroup (Swiss: C.SW - news ) (+2.2 percent) and Bank of America (Swiss: BAC.SW - news ) (+2.2 percent). 
Controversial drug company Valeant Pharmaceuticals International (NYSE: VRX - news ) gained 5.7 percent, recovering some of its losses in the prior two sessions after a research report accused the company of inflating its sales figures. 
A handful of companies suffered bruising declines after reporting disappointing results, including footwear maker Skechers (-31.5 percent), online radio company Pandora Media (NYSE: P - news ) (-35.4 percent), cybersecurity company Fortinet (-19.3 percent) and waste-disposal company Stericyle (-19.3 percent). 
Dow member Procter & Gamble rose 2.9 percent after it reported earnings from continuing operations that translated into 98 cents per share, three cents better than analyst expectations. 
Bond prices fell. The yield on the 10-year US Treasury rose to 2.08 percent from 2.02 percent Thursday, while the 30-year advanced to 2.90 percent from 2.86 percent. Bond prices and yields move inversely.
